awd_titl_txt: Build and Broaden: Strengthening Social Science Research Infrastructure at the University
awd_abstract_narration:
Social science research is limited by a lack of high-quality data about public opinion on numerous minority populations. This lack of high-quality data is often due to a lack of social science research infrastructure. This lack of infrastructure is related to crippling debt, consecutive years of catastrophic natural disasters, rapid population loss, and limited access to support from the national government.  This project is a collaboration between an established institution in survey research and a MSI to strengthen social science research infrastructure at the MSI and to improve infrastructure for measuring and analyzing public opinion about an underserved and understudied minority population. The project builds infrastructure that will aide in the production of academic research in and on a minority population and will provide a voice, through opinion polling, to the heretofore understudied population. In addition, the survey infrastructure established will provide University affiliates at the MSI with access to a much-needed research tool to advance their scholarship.
 
This project will initiate a new, long-term collaboration between the MSI and the University of Michigan to collect, organize, and disseminate data on public opinion, political behavior, and political institutions of an underserved population. The goals of this partnership are to: (1) provide the MSI's faculty with high-quality tools to support and advance their research agendas; (2) provide both undergraduate and graduate students at the MSI with research opportunities and training; (3) provide researchers at academic, governmental, and nonprofit institutions with high-quality data that advances research on the population of interest; and (4) provide a scientifically validated vehicle to accurately capture the political, economic, and social preferences and experiences of members of the understudied population.  At the end of this first phase of this collaboration, the team expects to have the following in place: a survey design; a sampling framework; a data collection plan that maximizes the representative nature of the survey while minimizing costs; a plan to ensure the financial and logistical sustainability of the infrastructure; quality control checks; and a plan to disseminate and archive the data in a way that supports local institutions and researchers. By building infrastructure to collect, organize, and disseminate data on public opinion and other political dynamics, this collaboration will create many new possibilities to support the research of the MSI's students and faculty.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The NSF-funded project centered around the establishment of the Laboratory for Public Opinion Research (LabPOP) at the University of Puerto Rico (UPR). LabPOP served as the vehicle for furthering two goals. First, we developed and implemented a curriculum to enhance research capacity in Puerto Rico and contribute to the academic and professional success of students at UPR. Second, we improved the infrastructure for measuring and analyzing public opinion in Puerto Rico.  In doing so, we have built a critical foundation for providing  the academic, governmental, and advocacy communities with the high-quality, representative data needed to better understand the views and experiences of residents of Puerto Rico.

Intellectual Merit: High quality data on Puerto Rican public opinion is time-consuming and expensive to obtain, and, as a result, out of reach to most scholars and students in Puerto Rico. These costs are magnified by the fact that Puerto Rico is excluded from most surveys studying public opinion in the U.S., and also not included in high-quality comparative or international surveys. To fill this consequential gap in existing data sources, we developed and employed an innovative approach to sample design in areas without standardized address systems to construct what is arguably the most representative sample frame to date in Puerto Rico. We did this by going door-to-door and enumerating over 26,000 housing units throughout the island, with particular attention paid to ensuring that communities that are typically underrepresented (e.g. lower-income areas, areas in the center of the island, and rural communities) were represented in proportion to their share of the population. 

Equally important, we sought to ensure that this data would offer particular benefits to students and faculty at UPR. To do so, we developed and deployed a curriculum and mentoring plan through LabPOP that invests in students’ technical skills, data tools, and research experiences. Student participation in LabPOP has yielded significant success thus far, according to a post-participation assessment of students who participated in the first phase of the project.

Broader Impact: The lack of resources to support research at UPR has limited the public’s ability to keep government transparent and accountable, and to discern how to improve the design, adoption, and implementation of policies that could improve the livelihood of residents. This is particularly important given that residents of Puerto Rico have no formal vote in the federal bodies of government that serve as the ultimate authorities on their legislation and budgets. The importance of this data is magnified by the compounding crises affecting the island’s population, including the government’s financial challenges, consecutive years of devastating natural disasters, massive population loss, and limited access to federal support. Investments into infrastructure that can help researchers capture the experiences, needs and preferences of Puerto Ricans is absolutely critical to Puerto Rican scholarship, as well as the democratic health and future of Puerto Rico.

Summary of Outcomes: This NSF-funded project has successfully enhanced the research capacity of Puerto Rico by training a new generation of social scientists and building high-quality infrastructure for studying public opinion in Puerto Rico. The intellectual contributions of this project, particularly in developing innovative sampling methodologies, will address critical gaps in public opinion research. The comprehensive training and practical experiences that we have institutionalized in the UPR curriculum have equipped students with valuable skills that will enhance their academic and professional trajectories.

Through these efforts, the project has not only contributed to the field of social science research but also had a lasting impact on the broader academic community by fostering diversity and inclusion in the U.S. scientific workforce. The institutionalization of the LabPOP program at UPR ensures the sustainability of these efforts, making high-quality research training consistently available to future students and faculty members.

This project exemplifies the transformative potential of targeted research and training initiatives in addressing critical gaps and fostering the development of human capital in underrepresented regions. The continued collaboration and dissemination of the project's findings will further enhance its impact and contribute to the advancement of social science research on a global scale.
